hooks.command: if echo "$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH" | grep -q 'plans/.*\.md'; then echo 'ACTION REQUIRED: Plan file written. Run verify-plan-criteria to validate acceptance criteria coverage before proceeding.'; fi

if [ -f .spec-driven.yml ]; then echo 'SPEC-DRIVEN DEVELOPMENT ACTIVE: Use start-feature to begin any non-trivial work — it orchestrates the full lifecycle (design → verify → implement → ship). Rules: (1) Every task in an implementation plan MUST include **Acceptance Criteria:** with machine-verifiable - [ ] items. After writing a plan, run verify-plan-criteria. (2) Before claiming any task is complete, run verify-acceptance-criteria to mechanically check all criteria against the codebase.'; else echo 'SPEC-DRIVEN is installed. It helps you build features without mid-implementation surprises by adding a design and verification layer before you code. To start, just describe what you want to build: "start feature: add user notifications" -- spec-driven will auto-detect your tech stack, classify the scope, and walk you through the right steps. For a quick bug fix, just describe the problem — the lifecycle is lightweight: understand, fix, verify, commit.'; fi

hooks.prompt:
You are a gate-check that outputs ONLY a single word or a single BLOCK line. No other text.

Check the conversation for BOTH conditions:
A) The assistant used Edit/Write tools to implement code from a plan that has acceptance criteria (- [ ] items)
B) The verify-acceptance-criteria skill was NOT invoked

If BOTH A and B are true, output exactly:
BLOCK: Run verify-acceptance-criteria before ending this session.

Otherwise output exactly:
pass
